Award.AbstractNarration: The Video Bioinformatics Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) brings together expertise from engineering, information technology and life sciences to open new doors by enabling the study of continuous and dynamic biological processes in living systems that are captured live by video in real-life experiments. Traditionally, living systems have been studied as static images; scientists must infer the processes that produce growth, disease, healing, and death. The scientific community does not yet have a systematic way of examining moving biological images and understanding their dynamics. This IGERT addresses the need by bringing experts from widely divergent backgrounds and by integrating multiple imaging modalities with computational techniques for video data mining, knowledge discovery and visualization. Each student will participate in an intensive summer workshop before the first year of graduate study. A new interdisciplinary curriculum will train the next generation of engineers and scientists to solve old and new biological and computational problems. Information technology students will learn about the unique needs of studying living systems, and develop methods to enhance the study of these systems. Students in the life sciences will learn how to develop and apply effective computing techniques to dynamic biological problems. Interdisciplinary project-oriented team-taught courses and group projects are important educational elements. The program provides continuous mentoring, teaching and leadership opportunities, internship in industry or government, weekly seminars, yearly retreats, and workshops on ethics and communication skills. The program will aggressively recruit students from groups underrepresented in science and engineering. The research impacts a large number of fields where one must analyze massive video datasets and need highly efficient and effective ways to retrieve information. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vision of our IGERT on Video Bioinformatics was to integrate expertise from the life sciences, computer science, and engineering to enable breakthrough capabilities in understanding biological processes that are by nature continuous and dynamic. Our IGERT on Video Bioinformatics was at the intersection of engineering/computer science and life sciences and interdisciplinary education and training. Life Sciences students gained an understanding of the engineering principles involved in multiple Engineering fields and in Information Sciences. Engineering students learned biological imaging techniques, skills for the design of experiments and modeling of phenomena, and the needs of the biological community.

Intellectual Merit: The fusion of the two broad disciplines (life sciences and informatics) in our research and training program allowed the development of new tools that enabled solving old and new biological and computational problems. The project developed innovative research and training in biological sciences, video understanding, learning, and database development of dynamic biological processes, creating technologies for cell video analysis, modeling and retrieval. This greatly enhanced the abilities of biologists to discover, refine and validate biological pathways. The new understanding of spatiotemporal dynamics of cellular processes provided important breakthroughs in cell, molecular and systems biology where encoding proteins must be studied using high-throughput approaches to understand the functioning of an organism/cell by integrating all the interdisciplinary components involved.

The IGERT developed advanced techniques, fundamental algorithms and technology which  provide quantitative thinking, greater sensitivity, objectivity and repeatability of life sciences experiments. This makes it possible for volumes of video data to be efficiently analyzed, and for fundamental questions in both life sciences and informatics to be answered. Our research received many awards, including NSF community and judges’ awards in nationwide competitions of all IGERT projects. Our research also appeared on the Cover Page of a top journal. Several tools were developed (StemCellqc, TipQuad, EndoQuant, etc.) for analyzing biological video data. A book on Video Bioinformatics (Editors Bir Bhanu & Prue Talbot) http://www.springer.com/la/book/9783319237237#aboutBook was published by Springer in its Computational Biology Series in 2016.

Broader Impacts: This project trained a new, diverse generation of scientists and engineers to develop breakthrough technology for biological research. Automated methods for comprehension of the spatiotemporal dynamics of cellular molecules/processes will have an enormous impact in quantitative cell biology by characterizing phenotypic responses and constructing predictive models. This will advance a wide range of biologically important areas from the discovery of proteins to improved quality/yields of agricultural products and human health. A great benefit will be increased productivity, improved sensitivity, and enhanced analysis of data. Spatiotemporal video analysis, querying and indexing may benefit a large number of fields: news, entertainment, weather bureaus, libraries, and security/intelligence agencies all must analyze massive video datasets and need highly efficient/effective ways to retrieve information.

We developed an innovative graduate research, education and training program that provided a balanced education for students (without increasing their course load) with disparate backgrounds in engineering, computer science and life sciences. Our unique curriculum was based on the fact that both genome sequences and video imaging are essential to understand the dynamic processes of living things. The challenge was to design an innovative and highly interesting interdisciplinary curriculum and training program that exposes students to multiple imaging modalities at varying spatial and temporal resolutions and associated computational methods for video mining and knowledge discovery. Our interdisciplinary education effectively fused life sciences with engineering and computer science.

We developed and received approval from the various Academic Senate Committees for seven new IGERT graduate courses in Electrical and Computer Engineering: EE 270 Introduction to Video Bioinformatics, EE 271 Multiscale Analysis of Biological Systems, EE 272 Introduction to Imaging Bioinstrumentation and Analysis, EE 273 Live Imaging and Analysis of Cellular and Molecular Behaviors, EE 274 Introduction to Medical Imaging and Analysis, EE 275 Project in Video Bioinformatics and EE 276 Colloquium in Video Bioinformatics. EE 270, 271, 272, 273, and 274 are cross listed with the Genetics, Genomics and Bioinformatics (GGB) graduate program. EE 271 is cross listed with Bioengineering. These courses are required courses for all IGERT fellows. Non-IGERT students also take these courses. The courses are shared by the IGERT faculty. Each course carried two units and there was a lab every week during the 10 week quarter. Life sciences and engineering students were paired in a team. We provide continuous mentoring, teaching and leadership opportunities, internship in industry/government, dedicated space, internal/external program assessment, weekly seminars, yearly retreats, and workshops on ethics and communication skills.

We recruited a total of 31 fellows, of whom 25 are expected to complete PhD and 6 MS degrees. There were 16 males, 15 females and 10 under-represented minorities (URMs). IGERT fellows have been placed in both academia (as tenured Assistant Professors, Post-doc at Yale, Loma Linda Univ., UCLA, etc.) and industry (Abcam, Honeywell, APL/JHU, Brain Vision, etc.).
